title: 1D motion - analysis of a velocity-time graph

content.question: A graph of velocity <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math> as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> for the one-dimensional motion of an object is shown. The object has an initial position <math alttext="x sub 0 equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Which of the following statements best justifies whether the object will return to position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> during the time interval <math alttext="0 is less than t, which is less than or equal to 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>â‰¤</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> s</mtext></math> ?

choices.label: No, because the distance between the object and its initial position is increasing during the entire time interval.
No, because the object has a constant acceleration during this time interval.
Yes, because the velocity of the object is zero at <math alttext="t equals 3 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><mtext> s</mtext></math>.
Yes, because the acceleration of the object is negative during this time interval.

content.answer: No, because the distance between the object and its initial position is increasing during the entire time interval.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
